values:
Trying to get things done, moving ahead on some things but falling further behind on others. Aaaaah!

Friday was met with whirling snow and freezing roads. It took me two hours to get home. A good chunk of that was just trying to get out of the city in bumper-to-bumper frozen slush. I watched drivers charging ahead as soon as the car in front moved 5 feet. I'm amazed I didn't witness any accidents. Even when we began to break away into the rural roads, it was difficult. Averaged 40 km/h in an 80 km/h zone, and even that felt too fast sometimes, especially on hills.

Spent a few hours Friday and Saturday night doing work and shipping it out.

At least M. now has their first bank account. The teller was having some trouble with the system. While she was on the phone with the help desk, her "mentor" came in, said something and then followed it up with a tap on the shoulder and a brusque "Didn't you hear me?" I took an instant dislike to her. I always get angry with the petty tinpot dictators drawn to the little fiefdoms where they can exercise their power to make others miserable. I see them in schools with bullying principals, in health care, and this weekend in the bank. Any location where the customer is in fact a supplicant, vulnerable due to age, health or means.

Got new winter boots for M. Took the family to Wal-Mart so M. could get Xmas presents. Had lunch there. E. was terribly frustrated in the toy aisle because I wouldn't buy anything but kept saying, "Wait until Christmas, see what Santa Claus may bring". Got the groceries. By that time the kids were flagging and so was I. I still had some errands to do but their importance was vanishing under my fatigue. Came home. Eventually made home-made pizza for dinner.

I had meant to go to a tree-trimming party on Sunday and see a bunch of friends, but ended up cancelling. Bad morning sucked up all the oxygen and I just couldn't justify the four-hour round-trip. Did some work on the book. Gave E. a hair cut. Got D. to give me a hair cut too as the breakage has been terrible lately.

It sucks that even after coming home for the weekend, doing a bunch of company work, family work and contract work, you still feel behind the eight ball on Monday morning. I need more time and focus to get the book done.

Among the many gift basket inserts and glossies in the paper these days, there was an Oakville magazine for their moneyed residents. I see chunky cylindrical gemstone bead necklaces and bracelets in sterling silver are in, as are fuzzy "faux lamb" or distressed chenille scarves. Check and check. However the look is a bit cold. Earth tones are more my thing.

Also in the paper was a "Classic Creations" mag for a pricey Toronto jewellery store, filled with pictures of malnourished blond females wearing slave-girl bracelets and heavy earrings. The one cool thing I gleaned from there was the vogue to facet pillow cuts of opaque semi-precious stones that normally receive the cabochon treatment, e.g. agate, lapis, opal, moonstone, turquoise and hematite. The agate and turquoise photographed well. Sadly some of the pieces remind me of throat lozenges or Thrills candy... :-)

Ai yi yi.

Hosted a family from Skrael Friday night. Mother and daughter both entered in Pent, a lot of work. I hope they were comfortable.

Earlier this week I thought my left rear tire was getting a bit soft. Asked Albrecht to look at it, he didn't agree. Managed to convince myself by Thursday that I was just imagining things. I didn't drive Friday. Saturday morning, the car fully loaded, everyone clean and prepared, we left on time. Got partway down the street and I could hear the tire dragging. Turned around, deposited the family back at the apartment (E. already wailing) and limped the car to Canadian Tire.

In theory the tire might have been salvageable, but that would have meant lying in snow, trying to extricate the donut (which is mounted under the car and is very hard to remove), jacking up the car and possibly wrenching my back removing and reattaching the nuts before I could go to Canadian Tire to have the tire checked and possibly patched. It all would have taken time, and I had promised to get Albrecht to the event on Saturday. I was not up to it.

Instead I drove it flat the 3 km and was unsurprised to hear it had to be replaced. The clerk on duty was new and eager and scheduled me right in. Watching through the window I was pleased to see the technician check all the other studs after he affixed the new tire.

However that was a cool $175 I hadn't planned to spend that morning.

Got the family back into the car and we eventually got to the event. At least the blinding snow glare and black ice patches had passed by the time we started driving again. And the kids were able to eat more of their breakfast.

Part of the day did not go well. We were late and missed morning Court. I got the kids and myself dressed, and wrapped Albrecht's turban (he was going Persian for the day). 'Cenedl kindly dropped off my judging sheets. I went into the main hall, found the first entry, and ... it was very crowded. Very noisy.  As I sat down someone demanded loudly that we get started. There was a distinct undercurrent of anger at the table.

I suddenly realized I was not up to a fight.

I excused myself.

Had Albrecht return my blank judging sheets to the master table and spent most of the day looking after E. and feeling stupid.

I have judged at KA&S for almost a decade. I judge Pent entries. I judge papers. I judge day-of single entries. I love judging. Not yesterday.

Later I was told by a couple of different people that the negative vibe I sensed progressed to shouting. Maybe I'm not so stupid after all.

I have a certain amount of not-very-useful prescience. It knew before I did that I wouldn't be home for Hallowe'en (and that therefore there was no point in figuring out a costume). Evidently it also knew I wouldn't be doing much in the way of judging. I really have got to listen to that voice, because it's getting more and more reliable as I get older and accrete more data. I sometimes call it my Procrastination power, because generally if I procrastinate there's a very good reason why, I just don't know what it is for a while.

I'd like to thank Jhone for coming to me late in the day and asking if I was up to judging "just one thing" so that I wouldn't feel like my day had been in vain. Tarian happily answered a ton of questions about her lovely stained glass and by gum I did submit one judging sheet after all.

I'd also like to thank Keja for recognizing how crappy I felt for letting them down and reassuring me.

Finally I'd like to thank Jhone and Keja for locating and sending Albrecht and I our judging sheets from last year's KA&S. That meant a lot to us.

I got to spent time with Rachael and Tangwystl and give them little Xmas presents. Rachael gave me a reproduction Tudor pewter spoon!!! Kuel!

A couple of months ago Albrecht and I made a special trip to the Orange Bag Store and I picked up a piece of dark red silk brocade, even though the pattern wasn't really period, because you can't go there and not buy anything. I figure it's good for a mid-16th century Venetian bodice and sleeves, with a brown cotton velveteen skirt and dark bottle-green velveteen somewhere. It was nice to be able to show it to Tangwystl. One among many projects that are on hold until I get the book done.

The best part of the day was when Albrecht's research paper, "The Habit of Combat: What Fencers Wore" won first place in the category. (His paper won last year, too!) This year he got a great red riveted suede folder with a little tasselled bag inside containing a mickey (empty). I may induce him to put rum in there, for future reference.

Now we're sprawled about the living room in various stages of dress, watching the end of Ice Age: The Meltdown for the umpteenth time, nibbling on offerings from Timmy's and basically avoiding doing anything resembling work. But I foresee coffee will end this blissful state abruptly.

In FB conversation with Larisa, the topic of doing it all came up. She quoted, quite rightly, the culture of "keeping up with the Joneses" as inflicting just as much hurt as beauty magazines do to a girl's self image.

Maybe what's more worthwhile is declaring what we've already done and what we gave up for those things. A recent post by a celebrity blogger essentially admitted that she had to ignore (as in IGNORE, not just put on hold) her husband and kids to keep up on appearances. Which seems to cancel out the accomplishments. Which is more important?

As a post-modern woman (per my mother) I try to give attention to the ingredients I have chosen to include in my life. I chose to have a husband. I chose to have kids. I chose to build an engrossing job. I chose to have cats. I choose other things too, but the things that are already here get priority. If I jam too many ingredients in there everything suffers. We all have living standards, but let's face it, as long as no one gets food poisoning and the kids aren't cold, there's a fair amount of leeway on how clean a house actually has to be.

Maybe it's more important to proudly state what we actually did get done in a given day - and what we had to ignore to get those things done. Maybe if we're honest about the sacrificial backbeat we can get our priorities straight and stop feeling guilty about woulda shoulda coulda looked like Martha Stewart's airbrushed cat hair-free menu for living.

Yeah.

Today:
Stat holiday for me. Got up at 7:30 am. Did some work email. Comforted my daughter who's been sick and listened to some prattle without getting impatient. Brushed her hair. Helped make sure folks took their medicine. Petted the crazy cat and the sane cat. Put sick husband to bed. Rest of day: TBD but will include a pot roast and work on the book.

Yesterday:
Woke to a chorus of coughs from the family. Got medicine and juice at Shopper's Drug Mart. Doctored my family. Attended Remembrance Day Service via TV - if I sing all the songs, stand with the audience, pray and show reverence during the 1.5h service it counts and it's still an example to the kids. Did 2 loads of dishes. Made hot lunch of spaghetti and home made meatballs (deferred from Sat). Cleaned messy spaghetti residue off table and carpet. Got someone to feed and water the cats. Broke one of my prized captain's chairs, though hopefully it can be fixed. Dropped D. off at long-awaited SkyFall movie. Took kids to Value Village. Bought trinkets and books to build Xmas presents. Got stuff for M.'s Halo costume build. Got kids fruit smoothies from Tim Horton's (so tired of finding half-eaten double chocolate donuts ground into the seats). Moved furniture around. Scolded kids into shoes and coats so I could pick up D. from the movie. Fended off demands from kids for game tokens so they could play in the arcade. Reheated remains of lunch for dinner. Reminded D. to call relative. Helped supervise kids' computer/XBox time. Alternately broke up/escalated squabbles. Did 2.5h of company work laced with YouTube songs. Wrote a snippet of Remembrance day prose for FB. Snugglebunnies. Oh, and probably had too much caffeine.

What I didn't do: Get sick (yet). Write for the book, except mental notes. Meaningful personal care. Exercise, unless walking through Value Village counts. Diet.

Yes, we have laundry and dishes and recycling to go out. I need to plan Xmas stuff. I need to finish the book before it turns around and eats me.

Back in Canada.

I observed the cloud layers as we began our descent from 40,000 feet. The sun was setting behind the plane as we pursued the East. The first thick layer, crumpled, clean and white had obvious currents. Ice floes of cloud circulated between mounded snowy banks. It so resembled spring break-up. Stretches of white were marked with curved paths, like the indentation of feet in soft wet snow. The second layer was finer grained but deeper, with dark gaps over small bodies of water. We passed into a tall misty wall, the demarcation point between sunset and twilight. The final layer was small patchy clouds, broken and stirred.

Below I saw neat squares of land, punctuated here and there by a light. No cars. Restful but lonely. Was that the farmland south of the 401? And then, imperceptibly, the glint of mica and pyrites arose, first scattered like flowers to my searching eyes, then joining in orderly patterns and strings of beautiful light. The city a serenely glowing bank of coals. The plane banked considerately in sweep after sweep, displaying its birthplace with pride.

Then the controlled scream of descent, the startling bump mid-air as the landing gear were deployed preparatory to landing. Always the whispered prayer of gratitude and hope that we will land safely. We are passing over the highway now, the cars very close and individual, the FedEx crossdocks busy will that truck back in safely? here is the runway DOWN BUMPY SHAKEDOWN ow WHOOHHHHHHHHH as the plane forces itself to slow down.

A long ride to the correct gate way down at one end, lurching over the pavement expansion joints. A long wait on this little Jazz plane before they will let us climb down the steps. Somnolent no more, we are all tensed in the aisle or on the edge of our seat, itching to snatch that overhead bag, clear Immigration and find a washroom. The cold night air teases us. The stewardess shivers, wishing they would get on with it.

Finally some signal is made and the herd surges forward brusquely. Efficiency is driven by need. We march down the steps and grab the indistinguishable black suitcases from the SkyService rack. I would congratulate myself on my choice of plum, but in this light it too looks black and I feel a momentary stab of panic before I find it, second last on the rack. Back in formation, stomping down the narrow hall separated by glass from the comparatively happy, relaxed people sitting in clumps by the many regional gates. It is a long way to Immigration. The declaration card marked "Do Not Fold" is clenched in my hand as we walk past a gatekeeper sitting on a stool, and finally merge into the stanchion maze that leads to the immigration counters.

Glowing signage above repeats over and over, "Welcome to Canada / Bienvenue au Canada". Smiling attendants sort us into this line and that, but it isn't busy. I am controlling my relief and near-tears to be entering my own country again. The attendant takes my card, scrawls on it, asks a question and hands everything back. We walk down another hall and hand our marked cards to new attendants. Then we rush towards a great open door with the largest sign, "WELCOME TO CANADA", and beyond the door the families stand, their smiles in the beckoning darkness stealing into the lighted hall so that you are embraced before you even see them.

And you're home.

It's technically been a weekend. I remember sleeping in a bit, and slopping around in my pjs on the computer a bunch. But I also remember a long stop at Mr. Lube to get an oil change and a headlight fixed, and driving to Caledon 1.5x (had to turn around just outside Erin and go back to Guelph because I forgot the stupid receipt) to return the unsold Scotchtoberfest booze to the LCBO and to introduce Albrecht to the marvel that is Caledon Burger Co. Darling E. cried most of the trip until she fell asleep. We think she's fighting off something.

And then today we had to drive all over Guelph in the steady rain (that turned to snow at one shining moment) to pick up a bunch of stuff and buy a (miniature secret NOT) camera and a suitcase and find a pumpkin that wasn't half-rotten. At the mall the kids were entranced by all the media (Cinema One; HMV; EB Games) and it was just one long gauntlet of NO. So it's worth celebrating that we hadn't reached the outright snarling stage by the time we hauled our rained-on groceries into our happy home.

Caledon Burger Co. has very, very good burgers. Their fries are excellent too, cooked in cholesterol-free (?) rice bran oil which they sell by the jug. Skip the bottled Jones pop and get a can of Coke. I wonder if there are any decent antique shops lurking in Caledon East that we could use as an excuse to go there again sometime.

Because I need to take decent photos on the upcoming trip, today we went to Black's and bought a "Rebel" Canon digital SLR, beginner level that even an idiot like me can probably use. Also got a tripod that I hope will fit into the suitcase once I break it down a bit. And a bag. And a memory card. And a "filter" whose sole purpose apparently is to break and protect the lense when I inevitably drop the camera.

Then I got a dark plum suitcase. In the past 17 years we've had a couple of suitcase sets, and the big ones still largely survive, but the little airplane-friendly ones invariably get broken or a cat pees on them, rendering them unusable. Yay. Now I have yet another pretty dark purple thing. I swear, they are really proliferating the last few months.

We also got Harry Potter: Deathly Hallows I and II so as to shut up the offspring. Earlier this year we obtained almost the entire set dirt cheap at The Beat Goes On, but these last two had to be purchased at retail price.

The best moment today, so far, was watching the splatty rain morph into big fluffy wet clumps of snow. By the time we parked at the mall the really and truly snow was flying fast and scudding up the windows. Outside, I realized (1) this coat is too thin; (2) where the heck are my gloves; and (3) I'd better bring a pashmina on the plane.

After the mall crawl we corralled all the groceries so the family won't starve while I'm out gallivanting. We left pumpkin purchasing a bit late, and the meagre selection remaining at the grocery store was rotting, but we were able to obtain an acceptable specimen at another store nearby. Yet another reason to wash my coat - mud and pumpkin gunk. M. wants this year's pumpkin to look like a Halo Reach helmet.

I've made chili which is now simmering on the stove on low, and there is a big bowl of chocolate pudding in the fridge that I will later cover with Oreo cookie dust and embed with gummie worms. It's tradition. I won't be home for Hallowe'en so by golly we're going to have some of it tonight.

Tomorrow I fly to Minnesota. Hopefully I won't run into much weather at any point of this trip.

Meanwhile the living room is depressing. Blankets, DVD cases, cookie crumbs, dirty dishes, kleenex, bits of toys, empty pop cans, dirty clothes and general stuff. At least laundry for the trip is in progress, courtesy of the wonderful A.

Had some fun messing up a Grope & Flail roast beef recipe for New Year's Day.

The beef acquisition step was a little silly, though. The recipe called for a 5 lb. rib eye beef roast. I've eaten my share of rib eye steaks, but a quick troll of the grocery store revealed no roasts of that kind. I binged the bell at the meat counter and a wannabe butler poked out. I told him what I wanted. He cocked an eyebrow and stated that he didn't have any and that such a thing would be very expensive, looking me up and down.

I showed him the recipe and asked if he could suggest alternative roasts. He said he personally only cooks prime rib roasts, and allowed that he might be able to carve such a roast out of a prime rib...? He made enough comments about the expense that I got annoyed and told him that as a matter of fact I bought two tenderloins for my son's christening. Thanked him for his time, left the meat counter and grabbed a big top sirloin off the regular rack.

You know, he didn't have to be an idiot about the stupid roast. He could have just said, Sorry, we don't have any on hand right now. Let the customer decide if it's too expensive rather than making assumptions. I was properly dressed and shod.

Anyway the recipe calls for a bunch of onion and garlic to be pureed with some olive oil. Then you blitz in some rosemary, thyme, parsley and peppercorns. Looks like a rather savoury aioli. Then you anoint the roast with kosher salt and cover it with the aioli and let it marinate for a while. I didn't want to waste any of the aioli so I ran a little water into the blender and poured it into the pan around the roast. Curiously the mixture smelled a lot like marinating chicken souvlaki, minus the lemon.

The original recipe called for half an hour at 450F on a pre-heated pan, but I'd already bedded it down in a casserole dish so I stuck with that. Then 1-1.5h at 300F, depending on the weight. Afterwards you're supposed to reduce the pan juices with some beef stock and 1/2 cup red wine of a quality appropriate to your social class. That's where me and the recipe mostly parted ways.

I had a bunch of fresh mushrooms to use up and a pan of bacon fat from breakfast, so I sauteed them slowly in the fat with some of the remaining fresh thyme leaves and then let them sweat under a lid.

Meanwhile I cut potatoes and carrots into rough chunks and roasted them with butter, pepper, salt and balsamic vinegar at the same time as the roast.

When the roast was almost but not quite done I poured the pan juices into the frying pan with the sauteed mushrooms and their liquor, and reduced it hard with the aforementioned declasse (the accent aigu is there if you look hard enough) red wine of an inferior vintage that came from a tetrapak. Placed the beef and vegetables in beautiful serving dishes we got for Christmas, poured the lovely gravy into a bowl and there was dinner.

Meat very good, tender and tasty. Coating was a little strong - next time I'll use a few less peppercorns - but very good nonetheless. Gravy was just excellent, and worked well with the meat and roasted vegetables.

Last night for New Year's Eve we did our annual Oriental dinner on pretty Japanese and Chinese plates we've been collecting for years. Very simple this year - grilled teriyaki chicken and a pork stir fry with udon noodles. Jasmine tea. Oranges and apples for dessert. But it looked nice and tasted very good. The chicken especially turned out well this year.

Just as we were sitting back from dinner, the town fireworks display began in the park behind our building. We had ringside seats. It was a great little display - lasted about 15-20 minutes. Saw a couple of new firework types I haven't seen before - great curlicues in gold and silver - and an odd large flower burst that sprouted golden circles at the end of each petal.

Then we watched a bunch of Much More Music dance videos, including some mouldy oldies I honestly had never heard before. Tres lame. But it was worth it to see Sir Mix-A-Lot erupt again. Ask a man if he knows any rap music and THAT song will be at or near the top of his list.

Another stupid busy week out of the way.

On November 14th I received a scroll assignment - the Pelican for Eyrny Ormarrsdottir, who was elevated at Wassail on Saturday. It's my first peerage scroll, and I wanted it to be special. Others had kindly provided the wording, so I only had the design to worry about. I thought of adapting the arch of St. Patrick's Bell Shrine, a late 11th/early 12th C. Hiberno-Norse house reliquary, and of building pillars below to surround the text.

Here is an image of the reliquary:
http://www.museum.ie/en/exhibition/list/metal-reproductions.aspx?article=7e17436c-a06e-4d02-9120-a5ae852323f5

I was out of town until November 21st. Once I got back home I was obliterated with general work and life insanity. Everybody got sick. As a result I couldn't start drawing until November 27th. I had to fly out again November 29th so the scroll had to be ready by then.

As I sketched the arch in pencil I decided to have it supported by two rams with knotwork horns, for Ramshaven. In contrast to the inspiration piece, I decided to leave a gap open between the arch and the hemisphere (which I had reserved for the Pelican in her Piety) to suggest a coronet, as Eyrny is a Baroness,

Once I had the filigree figured out and redrawn with brown ink, I painted it gold using Winsor & Newton gold gouache. It looked rather ethereal, beautiful but insubstantial. I wasn't sure what to do next, so I took the family to get groceries. Once I got back I decided to paint a small area black. As I painted, the void solutions presented themselves with the end result that the ram bodies became red. Albrecht had looked up Eyrny's heraldry for me, which was a purple diamond on a gold ground, so I decided to make the top jewel purple and to add purple diamonds to the columns and separate them with alternating red and black bars.

I took a break and watched the Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe while sketching birds on scrap paper so I could get the angles figured out.

The following night I painted the Pelican and her brood. I wanted to suggest knotwork in the mother bird's winds without having them fight with the arch design, so I brushed simple figure eights but didn't detail them. I am particularly pleased with how her wings turned out - the flight feathers are separated by narrow unpainted bars, which makes them gleam and look 3-D in person. The baby birds' wings are not quite as arched as I would like for a pair of squawking little leeches :-) but they're OK.

The next morning I had to fly to Winnipeg. I got up early and did the calligraphy. Unfortunately I couldn't visibly present the phrases as they were written. They were a little too long to fit in the space with the pen I was using. So I had to run the text as a continuous paragraph. Not my preference but I had to leave for the airport in a couple of hours.

Lady Brigid Larkin and her lord Henry very kindly brought the scroll to Wassail for me. I hope it went down well, as I was probably passing over northern Ontario when it was bestowed.

Congratulations to our Pent winner - loved the nettle theme, yummy meat pudding in a turnip, pale pink madder and daffodil yellow linen clothes, naalbinding and research paper. I run into the Virtues discussion fairly regularly but never feel part of the picture because the moral priorities I seek don't seem to really fit the list. Once I heard about the Norse list I felt a little better (thanks Hector for that Ursus article) but I'm not 100% sure my virtues have a home.

So here's my take:

Hard Work
No matter what, if I work hard I know I will get there. I don't respect it when people go part way and then languidly fall back in feigned exhaustion. Hard work is a virtue. Its crucible of self-denial proves my commitment.

Love
I think love is too easily dismissed and limited in scope to spousal and close family relationships. I think real love for friends and colleagues is possible and inspiring. Love makes burdens light and helps make it easier to see and do what is right.

Passion
I feel strongly, and as a frequently intuitive person I believe it is a strength. To be sensitive to beauty and goodness, to shed tears over evil and injustice, and to harmess that energy to drive my response is not, to me, a weakness. I don't strike blindly but I bear the emotion like a flag before my eyes. You can't write poetry without passion.

Independence/self-reliance
Doing things alone proves my worth and ability to do them at all. Yes, I know how to be a team player. And I know how to take things under my wing and be responsible for them and make them happen.

Faith and Hope
To me these are almost the same. Faith requires a future to have a point. And hope opens the door.

Loyalty
This is more often disparaged than used, because it ties you to someone or something who may not return the favour. But to date the work I have done in the name of loyalty has not repaid me ill. Loyalty lets me pass over the rough spots without bailing. It can be a necessary bridge of tolerance.

Courage
This I think everyone can agree on.
It's telling my husband everything will be all right while I am rolled into surgery for an emergency c-section. It's promising to teach a class somewhere in Ohio to people I have never met. It's receiving friends at my father's funeral with my smile in place for the sake of my mother.

Late in May Nicolaa asked me via the Signet if I would like to do a scroll for the Gunther. I naturally said yes but at that point I had no idea what the award was. About a week later I found out it was for a Court Barony.

Gunther is a good friend of ours and there are many things that we would like to honour.

I looked over my inspiration books for a week or so. I knew Gunther liked the scrolls I have been doing based on early period metal artifacts. By the time Murdee Melee came around I knew it was going to be a two page scroll, each 11x14 pergamenata.  I had decided to do a carpet page and an incipit page (the concept seen so clearly in the Lindisfarne Gospels). The carpet page would be an adaptation/build-out of the Sutton Hoo shoulder clasp. As for the incipit I had thought to make it very Lindisfarne-y, but more on that anon.

Although I hadn't yet started to draft the main wording, I had dreamed up a key line - "I will be the Kingdom's Man". This line was going to be visually separated from the rest of the text and specially calligraphied using the Lindisfarne composite letterform.

While at Melee I gave Nicolaa a verbal rundown of what I was planning to do and she was tres cool with that. So off I went.

The first thing was to rule out margins on the pergamenata. I don't have a slanted drafting board. I do everything on the dining room table with a flexible see-through ruler and a hard point pencil. I got both pages marked with 1.5" margins. I wasn't quite sure yet how to handle the incipit or text page so I ruled .25" margins most of the way to the top on that one and left it for the moment.

For the carpet page, as mentioned I had decided to use the Sutton Hoo shoulder clasp. It is a magnificent piece of jewellery, red garnets on gold and beautiful millefiori wafers of blue, black and white glass set in gold stepwork, topped by an outstanding pair of garnet boars and framed by garnet zoomorph knotwork, all on gold. Outstanding both technically and artistically.

Here is a picture from Flickr:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/thursday_dave/2357914145/

While building my pencilled grid for the central stepwork panel, I had some issues of my own. First, the extant shoulder clasp is based on odd numbers whereas I was using 4 x 4 based on the dimensions of the paper and my preference for measuring things by the quarter inch. So this meant a lot of subtle differences to keep the grid balanced. Different motif repeat (even, not odd, which can really affect your colour balance). Diamond shapes to connect the motifs instead of a single line of stepwork. And different fills for the motifs.

Here is the initial grid. I don't use graph paper so this is all from scratch.


Then I had to decide how to visually differentiate the motifs similar to the cloisonne glass in the original but on a different system. While the extant piece only has a couple of patterns plus the plain red, I ended up with 5. I had decided not to use red motifs as there would already be a lot in the surrounds and I needed to balance it with the blue/black/white more so than in the original. Once I was finished I marked the motifs with a brown micropen.

Here is the final grid:


An interesting feature of Migration/Ostrogothic/Anglo-Saxon metalwork is their fondness for garnet inlays over gold that has been scored in a regular pattern, which adds light and some sparkle to what can be a very dark though rich and beautiful gem. The same technique was found in the Staffordshire Hoard pieces dug up a couple of years ago.

Rather than painting the red areas of the grid in a straight fill, I decided to echo this jewellery technique by marking my unused grid lines with a red micropen and then painting each cell individually.

As I began to paint the red cells I experimented with the gouache mixture. I normally use a combination of cadmium red and quinacridone red as the first gives depth and opacity while the second gives colour and lightness.  By itself, cadmium red tends to turn a sort of clay colour and has no fire. In contrast, quinacridone is on the orange-y translucent side. But mixed together they give a good quality dark red.

Initially I didn't get the mix quite right. I rationalized that since I was painting the cells hopscotch to avoid running, the variances that naturally resulted as I firmed up the mix or as the mix became paler (due to refreshing with water as it dried in the seashell I was using) would actually add to the rippling jewelled effect I was trying to create. And more or less that was the case! :-)

Initially I had thought to paint the connecting diamonds pale ultramine blue to match what I was intending for the motifs but I decided on gold and I'm glad.



Now, as Gunther has been a Guardsman of the Royal City of Eoforwic, I knew the boars would be perfect as eofor means boar. I added knotwork trilliums to the base of the carpet page to represent Ealdormere. I was hoping to use bear's heads in the knotwork panels but that did not turn out as I will later relate.

Meanwhile I was trying to draw the darn boars. I was having trouble balancing the shapes, and had to sketch them a couple of times before they really took form. When they were properly balanced I used the brown micropen to fix them. As I lined the eyes the boars came alive. It was an odd, almost mystic feeling that I was performing a rite.

Now my work on these scrolls really didn't begin until after Melee. I was working on the scrolls most weeknights after dinner and almost all day on weekends. But I hadn't figured out any wording yet.

I knew I didn't want to do a conventional wording. Part of a scroll's magic for me is the reversal of time through poetry. The less modern-sounding intrusions or bureaucratese the better, yet these are official documents with specific requirements to make them SCA-legal.

So I sat down one weeknight with Beowulf (original + modern translation) and a couple of other books I have on Anglo-Saxon poetry. I knew I wouldn't have a problem generating good alliteration and assonance but I wanted to check the rhythms and how they are deliberately broken for emphasis.

The nice thing about Beowulf is that even though the word endings have changed, the English speech patterns haven't. And even though I couldn't read the words I could read the letters and get a feel not just for the alliteration but for how the phrases varied in length.

Once I felt I had the style cold, I went upstairs and sat on the bed for a couple of hours writing down homonyms and fragments of phrases that could represent the many things that Gunther has done over his twenty years in the Society. Albrecht and Elizabeth eventually came up and we did our free-association vocabulary game ("think of words that start with T", etc.). The game usually deteriorates very quickly into potty talk and Elizabeth didn't understand why we were laughing so hard. I didn't really come up with any extra words that were fit to use so I left my pages to marinate.

A few days later I sat down and assembled my bits and pieces. I knew I wanted to express a progression from Boar to Bear to Wolf (Canton to Barony to Kingdom) in conjunction with Gunther's maturation in the Society as an experienced warrior with heavy administrative chops and fine personal qualities.

I also wanted to keep the award itself a secret until the very end.

Heh. On Monday I returned from Easter travels to a scroll assignment for Coronation. As usual being crazy and short of time I decided to try and use mostly-authentic materials just to pile on the challenges. So I used a piece of goatskin parchment and oakgall ink from the goodies that Nicolaa brought back from Pennsic for me last year. And gold leaf from the stash I bought in 2003 for $29.95. Considering the rise in commodity prices, that stupid little book of gold leaf is probably worth close to $100! Weird. I've used parchment before a few times but normally prefer the greasy side. This time I used the dry side. What a mistake. This particular hide had far too much tooth and my oakgall ink bled freely, completely blurring my letters. Also the dip pen caught and stuck all the time. And for some reason the Guild of Limners oakgall ink stayed a light to medium brown. Not even remotely what I would call black. Don't know why. Anyway. For the design I decided to adapt an element from the Sollested horse collar (Denmark, 10th century). I've used the dragon terminals before but this time I used the topper instead. It's got a bit of the Jellinge vibe. It's got a couple of intertwined beasties with nice fangs. I drew it with pencil initially, then inked it in with the oakgall ink. I have NEVER used gold leaf before, unless you count sticking a tiny piece onto one proto scroll back in 2003 with little more than glue stick. I picked out a couple of writhing limbs that seemed best suited for highlighting with gold leaf. I gooped some acrylic gesso into a seashell and watered it down to the consistency of thick cream. Then I painted the stuff on in a couple of coats with drying intervals. Went back and built up some areas a little more. Of course, after I had done that I went back and read some gesso sottile recipes and apparently the acrylic gesso is only a starting point and not really a recommended one even as a base. Sugar is involved, for example. The parchment cutting, pricking the points, design and gessoing took up Monday. Tuesday night was our anniversary so we were out. Wednesday night I didn't do anything much other than email and blowing up Zuma. Thursday night was groceries, karate, banking and other busy stuff. So you bet your sweet patootie I had to do the rest on Friday night after work. Friday after dinner I sat down and drafted the text for the scroll. Then I worked on the gold leaf. I drizzled a little honey into a plastic cup, then watered it down a little. I painted that on the gesso patches as my attempts to make them sticky with warm breath through a straw were not working. Aurelia had recommended I drop a bit of high proof alcohol on those areas to reactivate the gesso but I couldn't find my tiny promo bottle of Smirnoff Vodka and I was pretty sure there wasn't much to activate anyway. Then I used an exacto knife to indirectly cut the gold leaf through the orange paper layer above. Then I rubbed a q-tip through my hair, glided it across the end of the mostly cut piece, and was able to attract it on so I could lay it onto the slightly tacky gesso. This technique worked pretty well and I was able to lay all the gold fairly quickly. Towards the end I was able to lay the pieces almost clean, which is not easy given how it wrinkles at the least provocation. I didn't bother with a leather cushion as I was taking the gold directly from the book, cutting through the orange paper layer to separate the pieces I wanted. In the end I used about two full leaves. This covered each section about twice. I also used the straw to blow up the loose edges of the leaf so it would double over onto itself and help avoid some of the waste bits. I don't have glassine parchment to use as a layer for burnishing. I do have some crappy pretend parchment that is fairly stiff and see-through so I figured it would do. I cut a small piece of that and used that to safely press down the leaf as I laid it. I didn't have a proper burnisher or muller. Initially I tried using smooth quartz pebble over the see-through stuff but didn't like it, so then I got out a little funky metal spoon, used the bowl and that seemed to work better. I don't know whether you're supposed to burnish in little circles or back-and-forth strokes. I tried a little of everything, various pressures and I guess the best way was little circles, with tempo but not too hard. That makes sense I guess. No vulgar comments people. Now I didn't have a proper brush either. I used a moulting unused make-up brush which I don't recommend as it was not really soft enough and it roughened the gold rather than cleaning up the loose bits. I did try to save all the little bits but my table has glints on it here and there. Some little corners came up a bit bare. I tried to fix those but screwed up, especially on the top portion, full of right angles, where my little honey experiment ended up smearing when I couldn't remember my own design. I was also using a metal tool to try and scrape away the excess adhering bits of gold and the tool itself left residue on the parchment. Not the win there. The gold definitely does not have a mirror finish but I was able to bring up some real shine. And it looked OK in Court. Not having time nor the proper setup to use the red lead (also a Pennsic goodie) I settled for modern red gouache for part of the design. And I hauled out my India Ink to refresh the outlines and fill in part of the design as I was really disappointed with the oak gall ink's lack of depth. I did the calligraphy last as I wasn't sure how the gold leafing would work. Was not happy at all with the pen catching and the bleeding, as previously mentioned. And another thing - the parchment really seemed to pick up ambient dirt from my hands so I guess I will need to buy cotton gloves for future projects (any ideas? I don't know where to buy such gloves). However I think you can tell it is gold leaf. The scroll has personality and strength even if the execution is comparatively crappy. But with only 12 hours work I think it will do. So next time it's back to the greasy side of the parchment. Here are some pictures: So dear Lady Avelyn of the Hedge, fellow scribe, enjoy. It's a messy scroll, but at least the ingredients are good.

Over many years I nurtured hopes, essentially, that the universe was sentient and would recognize me. That there are worlds of goodness beyond and above me who would reach out to me and help me climb up to them.

I had always held before me the ideal of true communication between individuals. I wanted to participate in this.

Before, for some years I conducted the experiment that the courage to expose feelings and thoughts in rawness and honesty would encourage and enable others to share theirs in turn. And I thought that people did desire to share their dreams and hurts but lacked opportunities to do so. I dared.

Yet the opposite of what I hoped for happened. I was judged, and the people I spoke to clammed up even more. I lost their respect. The friendships eroded.

I slowly, belatedly learned to shut up, though I still screw up. Working on gradually crushing the desire to reach out and any expectation that someone else will.

I can see the retreat, the dismissal in their eyes when I step just a little outside, just a little naked. Asking me to stop.

For years, I hoped to look into your eyes and see some of the fears and hopes that I feel. I hoped you would speak them to me and grace me with your trust. And that this trust would somehow elevate both of us, create something new between us and maybe something new in the world.

Not cool. That's me.

Not cool for wanting to really communicate. Not cool for thinking love should not be restricted to one's blood family. Not cool for being loyal. For acknowledging, and thus honouring, loss. For asking for help.

I kept thinking there would be more or greater mysteries I could break into or rise towards. Of greater communities. That spirits never fully leave. That God or gods would communicate, if asked earnestly and long enough.

Every evening for a week I have been working on a Book of Durrow inspired scroll for an AOA recipient with a Hiberno-Norse persona. I had hoped to make it a fairly close reproduction but as the week wore on I came to realize it would probably take 3 weeks of evenings to do properly. The original cross-carpet page consists of interwoven gripping horse motifs in red and deep yellow on a black ground with white and cream green accents. The incipit page was somewhat simpler, consisting of braided knotwork initial work and the same hierarchy of initials later seen in the Lindisfarne Gospels (dominating primary initial and 3 other sizes in diminuendo). Here is a link to the cross-carpet page: http://mattstone.blogs.com/photos/christian_art_celtic/book-of-durrow.gif Here is a link to the incipit page: http://www.biocrawler.com/w/images/f/f3/BookOfDurrowBeginMarkGospel.jpg I made a pretty good stab at the horses on the four horizontal rows. Unfortunately my vertical columns were the wrong size (too thick), which forced too much torque on the figures. In the end, out of time, I decided to erase my pencil work and leave the two small sections blank. I did briefly consider making them Royal signature zones but it didn't make sense for the rest of the art. While the original used a deep yellow, now flaking, I decided to use my gold gouache for that component. Here is a picture of the gold being laid in: Here is a close-up of the gold work: As I have said before, knotwork is basically taking a sine wave and putting a kink in it. The Durrow pages show exactly that. In fact, the incipit page I adapted (very sketchily, I might add) shows that concept in its simplest form as little tendrils beside the primary lines. So it's important to carefully plot out how the waves intersect and I did a fair bit of measuring as I went along. Too bad I didn't mark out the text lines before I started painting, as the incipit page looks slanted to the right compared to the cross-carpet page on the left. Due to the time required for the cross-carpet page I did the incipit page on Friday night and finished just before 1 am. Once I was finished sketching I traced over the designs with my brown micropen. Black tends to look too coarse, but the brown works. I loved laying in the gold, dark red (two gouaches mixed together to produce a strong opaque red) and black ink. I used a triple zero Kalinsky sable brush for all of the work. Most of it is very clean but I was tired on Friday so some of the black work runs into the gold a little. I had hoped to trace the white interlacing of the horses' limbs (with the alternate haunches in cream green, as per the original) but did not have the time. I also snatched up the wrong nib so the calligraphy is thicker than I had wanted. Frankly, the incipit page is nowhere near as nice as the carpet page but at least it doesn't compete too much. I did manage to give it the Coptic red dots treatment though. Here is a picture of the finished scroll: Albrecht says the recipient was happy.

Everyone has met that wonderful person with the open eyes and engaging yet confidential smile. In your very first conversation, they treat you like you're extra special and act like there is a treasured secret between you. You can't wait to figure out what it is!

Notice though, that the sparkling conversation is pretty brief and that soon the person moves on to the next new-cherished friend. Meanwhile you stand, a little dazzled and looking forward to talking to that person again because they made you feel so good for the few moments they engaged you.

That's charisma. The star quality that makes politicians. What Pratchett refers to as pixie dust.

The problem is that they don't actually have anything for you except their momentary attention. They remember your name, like a mnemonic tic. Without promising anything they convince you that they care, and they do, for as long as you affect their interests.

Perhaps because I am initially shy and slow to make friends, charisma is more dangerous for me.

I have rushed off, starry-eyed, any number of times to please charismatic people, hoping for more of their glamour. Spent money: spent time and tears. But their hearts are their own; you cannot win them with labour and they are immune to your sincerity.

Beware charisma.

Self-doubt is a hungry monster, and artisans and performers are particularly vulnerable to its avid embrace. At some point (and sometimes semi-perpetually) we will pathetically seek validation from anyone who will listen for five minutes.

Talking is therapy. People need support, especially if their art is a solitary one. But sometimes it seems more worthwhile if one witholds oneself and blocks off the need.

There have been situations where I was competing for attention with other similarly-needy artisans and the true adults in the room indulgently dispensed crumbs of comfort that I cropped up with zeal. But later I felt ashamed. Sweet in my mouth and bitter in my belly.

No one wants to continuously hear or reward twice-told self-aggrandizing tales of semi-virtue.

In a couple of weeks Medb and I are travelling to the Royal University of the Midrealm near North Canton, Ohio. I'm teaching a class on Gothic dress (including a draping practical) and a class called "Beyond the Book of Kells: Ripping off Celtic Motifs", which talks about finding SCA scroll inspiration in Celtic art.

The premise for the Celtic Art class is this: folks look at the Lindisfarne Gospels or Book of Kells, are intimidated by the incredibly intricate illumination, maybe try a bit of knotwork on a scroll and then give up. My class is about deconstructing motifs in the extant illumination sources - and then moving on to other pieces of Celtic art - chiefly metalwork, though stonework is another source - for elements one can re-use in scrolls. I'm talking about the Ardagh Chalice, Tara Brooch, Lismore Crozier, St. Patrick's Bell Shrine and lots of other pieces including Sutton Hoo and the latest Anglo-Saxon hoard.

I deconstruct a specific object and identify a striking, self-contained element, such as a gripping beast or interesting knotwork formation. Then I paint it in gold on the scroll and add decorative elements e.g. representations of millefiori beads or stepwork enamel inlay. I may adapt the beast or shape to suit my heraldic needs (e.g. change a man's head to a wolf, a triskelion to a trillium).

Secondly, I like to layer in the paint so I can create a 3-D effect. Inserting tiny droplets or thin lines of gold gouache at intervals on a flat gold ground gives the impression of repousse very typical of Celtic-era metalwork. With silver it would look very Norse but I prefer gold. Note to self: do some experiments to see if the silver gouache tarnishes or changes colour. As well, layering in the paint on a millefiori bead can really make it stand out. The overall impact is of real gold and jewels.

Last night I actually went so far as to do some advance cooking - Tijuana Barbecue, which is a pulled pork dish created by James Barber way back in the 70s. I hadn't made it in a long time. You brown a big 'ol pork loin on all sides in oil, high heat, then remove to a dish, turn down the heat and saute (imagine the accent) 2 onions sliced into rings. Add a can of whole tomatoes, cocoa powder, bay leaves, oregano, some garlic cloves, vinegar, cayenne, dried mustard and salt, bring it to the boil, put the pork back in and turn heat down to low and leave it covered for 5-6 hours until the meat falls apart. Very good on tortillas, rice or boiled potatoes tossed in butter, or just by itself in a sodden heap of intense meaty goodness.

Of course, I always up the cocoa and garlic (they're whole cloves, they turn into sweetness not acridity over the long cooking period, no stinkage) and add beer (I prefer Hoegaarden wheat beer) or white wine. For the Kingdom Arts and Sciences event a couple of weeks ago I was asked to create early period Award of Orion scrolls for a husband and wife. I didn't know them well but some Googling helped flesh out the wording. The husband was interested in forging, leatherwork, armouring etc. while the wife especially enjoys weaving, helping with feasts, the art of tea and soothsaying. So I did a very simple rhyming quatrain for the wife and a triplet for the husband. The Signet, Kersteken, suggested it would be nice to have the scrolls work together somehow. I love Celtic metalwork and thought it would be nice to split the design of an annular brooch down the middle and use that to unite the two scrolls when they are mounted side by side. I was inspired by the Hunterston and Tara brooches and by the enamel medallions on the Ardagh chalice (all 7th century). I inserted the award device into the brooch design. It's a little loud but what can you do. The current Royalty are attaching ribbon seals on their scrolls for this reign, which is great as it frees up space for design. Materials: Pergamenata, brown micropen, gold, red and purple gouache, india ink.

I was surprised and pleased to be assigned the Court Baronetcy stepping-down scrolls for the Rising Waters investiture. Their Excellencies have early period Norse-Anglo Saxon personas as I understand it, and I have a soft spot for Aibhilin. Master Hector had provided wording in advance using a Norse alliterative poetry format. I decided to do matching scrolls that would look good hanging side by side. I am drawn to Celtic metalwork and my inspiration for this set is St. Patrick's Bell Shrine, an 11th century "house reliquary" whose "roof trees" on each end of the box are beautifully decorated with gold filigree and enamel. The design is said to be created by Irish craftsmen heavily influenced by Scandinavian design. As a Baron and Baroness protect and nourish an entire community, I thought erecting a golden roof-tree shelter with twining knotwork and enamel medallions over the words of praise for their service would be appropriate. I did look at their heraldry (oak leaves and thistles) but I didn't see an easy way to tie it into the design as this sort of knotwork is highly stylized and adding acanthus-like shapes (for the oak leaves) would change the entire aesthetic right away. I also looked at their heraldic colours but decided to stick with red, black and gold in the medallions, which were inspired by the enamelwork on the 7th century Ardagh Chalice. I did the design freehand once I had a reference point. I played around with the compass but the freehand result was better so I stuck with it. As pergamenata is translucent, I was able to trace through onto the second scroll once I had the first design ready. I used a brown micropen to finalize the design. Then I used gouaches in red and gold plus india ink. On Friday night I sat down to do the calligraphy in Elder Futhark runes. I used an A-5 nib. Once I had the rhythm going I didn't dare stop but did both scrolls in succession. My hand was cramping and I was afraid I would screw up otherwise. Before I finished the first scroll I had memorized the alphabet and barely referred to it during the second scroll (except for the W, which looks like a sharp-edged P). I was pretty happy with the results. The calligraphy is reasonably consistent.

I volunteered to take a scroll for Crown. I was surprised and pleased when it turned out to be a Scarlet Banner for Baroness Nicolaa, my Laurel . Her Excellency has a fairly strong persona and so I wanted to design a scroll that respected it with a 13th centry Anglo-Norman feel, a style I haven't really done before. So I dug around the online British Library and found a few examples that I liked from manuscripts such as the Anglo-Norman verse Life of St. Edward the Confessor (wow! Bayeux-style storytelling), Guillelmus Gemmeticensis (Gesta Normannorum ducum), Royal 12 F XIII, Harley 4664 f.145v (lovely historiated initial of a fool), Royal 1 D 1 f.4v of Martin and the beggar, Arundel 233 f. 96v (historiated initial D for Domine, Psalm 101) and Harley 928 f.30 of Margaret emerging from the belly of a dragon (Lauds of the Virgin). Some of the scans had good views of their accompanying Gothic-y text. I'm not very familiar with Gothic but these examples look more transitional than pure Gothic yet not Carolingian either. I only have one book of calligraphic alphabets and it's not very good. I tried the Gothic example that looked most like my examples but it just didn't flow, so I ignored it and copied out a rough alphabet from the extant samples. That felt much better. I had been reading The Troubadour's Song by David Boyle, so for the text initially I looked at trouveres verse from the 12th century, including some from Blondel de Nesle, (according to Boyle likely one of Richard the Lionheart's lovers, yeesh. Gotta love sensationalistic history). Richard the Lionheart himself had written some songs and in one he used the same line to end each stanza for dramatic effect. This attracted me. I had decided to compare Nicolaa to the Roman goddess Diana (because the award was for archery), so I came up with the French line "Par raison on l'appelle Diane" (10 syllables) ("For good reason they call her Diana"). I did look at writing 2 or 3 stanzas of 7 lines or so, 10 syllables each. In the end I decided not to bother versifying the whole text as my calligraphy is not small and I would run out of space too fast. But I kept the Diana line. And rather than make the line a lacuna in a sea of English I decided to write the whole scroll in French - which caused an issue later :-) The other reason was that Nicolaa did my Award of Arms scroll several years ago in French, which touched me, and I felt this was a chance to return the favour. For the illumination I wanted to incorporate elements of Nicolaa's heraldry. Nicolaa has a registered device that includes a gold pall, red crescenty-things, and counter-ermine (white bits on black). The award she was to receive has black wolves, a red wavy line and white for contrast. I wanted to use blue for contrast. I decided it was best to historiate the N in her name, making the N gold, enclosing a scene of Nicolaa drawing the bow wearing a red dress wearing her characteristic veil and her coronet. The historiated initials found in this style of illumination often have diapering or chequey-style grids with little dots, ermines and other tiny designs in white, gold or sometimes red or blue on a contrasting background. Sometimes the grid lines are marked. So I laid out a grid on the entire initial but I didn't consider the fact that the outer border of the initial should have had its own grid. As a result the border diapering of counter-ermine (black with white bits) is too infrequent and off-rhythm. For the image of Nicolaa with the bow I was guided by an early 14th century ms (MS 47682, f.40, c. 1327-1335). It was later than my other sources but at least I could see the archer's stance. Unfortunately he was facing the wrong way and I didn't do a very good job reversing the stance. More importantly I could NOT draw a decent face (typical last-evening procrastination). I repainted it in white half a dozen times and finally gave up. Believe me, the blank white mask on the final is far better than the various haggish Joker visages I drew. Initially the background in the initial was completely white but it looked too stark, even with some little gold dots in the cross-hatchings. I had already done the azur border around the Scarlet Banner device, so I decided to fill in some of the diamonds in the initial with blue. I left some blank and the overall effect is nice. The wolves on the device turned out well, but they are rather individual and not the mirror images they should be. I didn't have time to work out marginalia (e.g. using her comet badge or any of her favourite things like cats or ice wine ) so I feel the scroll is a little bare, not as dressed as it should be. I didn't find a place to use her red crescents either. However, I did slide in some white work on the gold N and some extra dots on the blue border of the award device. I also outlined some of the text capitals in blue or red and added a row of multi-coloured circles, an element I saw in Harley 4664 f.145v. Note: I get the impression from some that whitework is hard. But after messing with tiny red dots on 8th century illuminations the whitework I attempted didn't seem too bad. What I found hard was not screwing up the counter ermine. I drew them in with pencil before I did the black fill, but had some trouble keeping them clean, so the diamond points are not that great. I am not happy with the calligraphy as I didn't really understand the hand and I was rushed. Probably the best examples are towards the end of the first column where the rhythm and tightness look best. On the second column I was working around some damp paint and the angle of letters keeps changing. I was writing the text from memory at some points rather than from my pre-printed herald's copy, and as a result committed an error in translation that is not on the herald's copy - "champ de l'archerie" should have been "champ d'archerie". I also wrote patiente as patientente (the hazards of breaking a word across two lines) and had to use some white paint to cover it up. If I had more time I would have figured out a little marginalia for that too, but as it was I was still up to 5 am the day of Crown. Such is my life. We couldn't stick around for Court as our guest needed to attend a Masquerade in Guelph, so I missed the presentation. I am quite sorry as I was looking forward to it, and I mercilessly chivvied Nicolaa's husband Gunther to let us know how it went. It's not often one gets to do an award scroll for one's Laurel! Especially one who has done two of my award scrolls. As Nicolaa does the court heralding I was curious to find out how they would hand off that scroll. Beaudoin had been there earlier and reads French so I thought they would grab him, but he left early as well, so they hauled in Baron James Mercer. Hope he didn't have any problems. Materials: pergamenta, gouache (cadmium red, ultramarine blue, white, gold), india ink, 000 brush, nib pen (C-4?), pencil, brown micropen.

One thing I tried to express to the ladies today was the incredible continuity in fabric motifs from the Coptic Christian finds to the present. In my books are many beautiful examples of repeating, complex motifs in silk and linen-based brocades, and the same styles and pleasing shapes show up again and again across Europe and Asia for over 1700 years and probably longer. There are regional and religious differences, and sometimes colour vogues, but overall I am more struck by the consistencies.

The tree-of-life emblem is probably the most well-known repeat in fabric brocades, but there is a remarkable example in Great Italian Textiles of a dark purpley-red brocade with an abstracted leaf-like repeat that is very modern in feel. It's amazing it survived but it is truly beautiful. Looking at it few people would say it was a renaissance pattern, as the motifs are angled/flying instead of the straight x-y. I sure hope the dating is right.

One thing I like about the Arts and Crafts movement is that it remembered but lightened certain artifacts of renaissance and Egyptian design and other periods. I don't feel that Arts and Crafts is dilute, and I love the beautiful wedding of less-popular metals, enamel and semi-precious stones in the jewellery as well as some truly airy wallpapers created during that era. There is an air of delicacy mixed with practicality.

Over time I have come to believe that with age and experience the mind develops the formulae necessary to predict or identify certain small personal or family events. There are many small cues we receive or perceive and cannot immediately, consciously interpret but do not throw out just the same. A "vision" of a family member's onset of final illness when I didn't know he was going to hospital, a pregnancy identified over a distance of thousands of miles for someone I barely knew, prediction of jury duty for another family member, confirmed the following week, moments of real life. Nothing useful of course, just interesting.

Yesterday I got up at 6:30 am to prepare our Thanksgiving dinner. We had four friends coming over in the afternoon and I wanted to give them a real feast.

David took care of all the cleaning, vacuuming, bathrooms etc., kept the kids out of my hair, and picked up last minute supplies for me.

This is probably the first big dinner where we haven't had to run off detailed lists to get everything done. We've finally had enough practice and actually the place looked pretty good and all the food was cooked at the same time. We didn't get into each other's face and I didn't get stressed until around an hour before the guests were supposed to get there, probably a record for me.

So the first thing I did, bleary faced, was to bake a pumpkin pie spiced with cinnamon, cardamom, allspice and nutmeg. While that was baking I scalded the milk and butter for the white rolls as it has to cool down before you can think about adding yeast to it.

Then I sliced 2 English cucumbers very thinly (unpeeled) and covered them with kosher salt, sugar, some vinegar and fresh chopped dill. It's a kind of Scandinavian fresh pickle that I picked up many years ago.

Then I peeled a bag of potatoes and put them in water to soak. By this time the rest of the family was awake and starting to percolate.

Then I started my ice ring. I have this jelly mold with rose shapes that makes perfect ice rings. Pour in 1" water, let it freeze, then place orange slices with a cherry at intervals along the sides, let them freeze to the ice, then keep topping with water until it's full.

I peeled carrots, chopped them into wedges and stuck them in a pot with water to wait. Meanwhile I yoinked the neck and paper sack of organs out of the turkey and threw them in a large pot with water, onion, carrots and celery, sage and thyme from my mother's garden, pepper and a little salt and set it to boil to make the giblet gravy.

Then I started the rolls. Matthew helped me mix in the flour, a cup at a time. It takes 7 to 8 cups of flour. After the 4th cup the balloon whisk doesn't work and I move to a long curved dough stick that I bought at a yard sale. It tames the thickest dough. The kitchen was warm from baking the pie, so it was easy to get the dough to rise.

Then I made some pastry for the apple pie and stuck it in the fridge to firm up.

Then I made cranberry sauce and warned the kids out of the kitchen. The sugar syrup can be dangerous if allowed to sputter (napalm anyone?) but no injuries. Once it had boiled down a little I threw in the package of fresh cranberries and in just a few minutes the skins had popped and it was, suddenly, jelly. Beautiful.

Once the rolls had risen the second time and been baked, I threw together the Granny Smith apple pie. It was a little more spicy than usual (I was lavish while grating the nutmeg) but still acceptable.

Then it was turkey time. We had brined the turkey for 24 hours in a bath of water, kosher salt, orange quarters, fresh ginger slices, peppercorns, star anise, mustard seed and a bunch of other things. Now I wiped it dry and put it in my industrial catering pan to roast. I stuck the ginger pieces and star anise in the cavity to keep scenting it, and I swapped the bird down with a mixture of butter and honey which bronzed it very quickly.

When the turkey was 2/3 done I quickly made stuffing with 5 slices white bread, 3 stalks celery, 1 onion and more sage and thyme, moistened with butter and turkey drippings and stuck the pan at the bottom of the oven.

I had planned to make a pumpkin cake as I picked up a cool recipe from work, but just didn't have time. I think I'll make it tomorrow in a bundt pan with the excess as cupcakes and bring it to work as a treat.

I put the potatoes and carrots on to boil while I got cleaned up and dressed. Then I dressed the table with pretty layered fabrics that my son and I bought on sale at Fabricland (black with a tiny gold acanthus pattern, covered with a sheer bronzy fabric with golden starflake shapes) and put out our glass dishes and the silverware. The rolls were in a white tablecloth in my seagrass basket, flanked by the pumpkin and apple pies, a bottle of wine, the punchbowl, cranberry sauce and dill pickle, then the mashed potatoes (I love my old-fashioned ricer!) mixed with butter and cream, and the bowl of carrots. Then the beautiful turkey was ready. I finished off the gravy (yes, mine is scratch, like everything else here, thank you very much) and poured it into the boat.

We received two beautiful flower arrangements from our guests (thank you Doughall and Gunther & Nicolaa!) in autumn colours which really finished the display.

Once we announced dinner I carved the bird onto a platter and set everyone loose. Strangely enough all I felt like doing for the first 15-20 minutes was to sit and beam at everyone eating and enjoy how happy everyone was. One of our guests was a little held up by traffic so after she arrived and had a chance to get her plate I started to feel a little more like having something myself.

Today we have ignored the dishes and snacked on leftovers and watched movies, which is the best way to spend the rest of the weekend. Breakfast was pie. Yum. David thought the pumpkin pie was all gone and was mourning over the empty plate, but I suddenly recalled I had baked some leftover pumpkin custard in a mini pan. It was great to present him with this little flower-lobed pan filled with yummy pumpkin stuff.

My turkey sandwich is making me dopey now (Hello Tryptophan! Word of the Week!) but I never regret cooking my brains out for good friends.

We have been fomenting cool clothes for the Althing next month. I have always regretted discovering the SCA in Eoforwic too late to catch the first Althing, Novgorod or the Italian event.

Down at Pennsic I found some nice embroidery threads and we both got to-die-for brooches - Albrecht picked up a Norse rooster brooch and I got a Frankish red and gold enamel uber-pin that he successfully "traded" for somewhere, said negotiations probably involving armed henchmen saying "YEAH". He also picked up a heavy white linen shirt that will do for most early period stuff.

After Pennsic I raided my wool bins and found enough to make Albrecht a tunic in dark purple light-weight wool, a good orangey-brown for Matthew and a rather organic blue that will be a cloak piece for someone. I'm going to dress Elizabeth similar to myself with a miniature apron dress over little tunics. I might even make myself a "Norse cap" albeit I consider these more Yorkish than anything.

But I wanted something more. Reading through Carolyn Priest-Dorman's notes, I was intrigued by the Norse coats found in some burials. Although these are apparently Birka-area rather than Icelandic, and probably Rus-inspired, they sounded cool. Now as it turned out, while we were visiting my mother in Gananoque the 1812 reenactors were in town and there was a fabric merchant. Her prices were high, but she had a "boiled wool" in a nubby greyish brown that I loved, so I bought just over 7 metres for $100.

So Albrecht's purple tunic is assembled. I'm going to bind the collar and cuffs with a piece of tawny gold shot silk that I am hoping to embroider a little. His long coat is cut out. Although I did his tunic by hand, I'll probably do the coat and most of the other items on the machine as I don't want to run out of time.

We don't have an A-frame and probably won't, but I was taken by Albrecht's description of Sigridr's tent covered with (probably Jellinge-inspired) norse shapes. If I have time I want to do a white banner with a Norse interpretation of Albrecht's device and his new brooch.

Having lots o' fun. Albrecht is getting excited!

I am making this an open post as maybe my SCA family will find it illuminating.

There has been a lot of ugliness in my life the last 18 months. Stuff at the workplace (you name it, it happened), my father's long illness and death (breathing apparatus now make me sick instead of vaguely curious), negative social politics and a larger than usual dose of bad world news.

When faced with bad, one fights to maintain, overcome or ignore. Just keeping going is the important thing until it passes.

I thought that my strong family life would neutralize the toxic effects of the ugliness (after all, none of it was self-inflicted so no side helping of blame/guilt) but this protection has not been absolute.

This lengthy bad spell has done something to me. It's not irremedial, and recognizing it now will go a ways to correcting it, but it needs to be said.

I've always been somewhat shy and quiet (but never mentally!) but now this is starting to border on neurosis - fear of joining gatherings/not feeling welcome. For example, I could NOT go to the CD release party at Trilliums as I felt I had to be personally invited (how stupid is that!) and I didn't feel I could join other campfires. I stuck to home base and my camp work.

Lately when people approach me I immediately tense for trouble. Very much a learned stimulus-response situation - those who know what I do for a living and some recent history may see exactly how logical this is. And there has been a lot of trouble, so bracing for impact has made a lot of sense.

I am suspecting everyone of hidden agendas. My native suspicion is taking over, along the lines of "Who would want to talk to me unless they had a bone to pick" sort of thing.

Kind of puts a damper on one's social life.

I'm not mad, but I'm not feeling too great.

Now here's the segue to part 2 of my story.

Like everyone else in the SCA, I've been exposed to my share of politics, enough to make me shy away from canton-level activity with some legitimacy. I got a strong enough taste of it from people at higher levels to make me disgusted with the whole advancement process. I said to myself, Who in hell would want to be a peer if you have to work with people like that. I guess you could say that I lost faith, not in the pursuit of excellence, but in the SCA's fundamental good will.

It was moot to me anyway, as I had a new baby to look after, but as I started to emerge from the 2.5 year hiatus that pregnancy and childbirth impose on extra-curric, I took up my crafts again with a blighted spirit. I was very lonely and I felt my isolation followed me to events and wrapped me like a cloak.

Now I'm not saying that all this has gone poof with a magic wand, but I want to point out a couple of things that happened at Trilliums.

I went over to Kersteken to deliver 2 scroll blanks, and for the first time was able to find out who Rachel is. Everyone at this point is laughing their @sses off, but I don't tie names and faces well, if ever. I saw this little middle-aged lady in black with Kersteken. And later, at Court, I heard that she had done this and that gorgeous scroll.

At Court, I saw people get awards. The awards were for A&S, and Martial, and Service, and all that. It was fun and exciting and everyone was happy.

But later on I was thinking about what, to my mind, united all of the recipients. Remember, everyone, that I was entrenched in suspicion mode. Earlier in the day a couple of friends had given my family a bunch of valuable useful stuff and all I could think was Why? What did we ever do to deserve it? and How will we make it up to them? I felt even more indebted, if this makes sense.

But I thought about the recipients and I guess I would describe the uniting quality as a universal generosity of spirit.

And this generosity isn't the kind of forced obligation ("I will do X and Y at ABC event because it is on my to-do list") but the thoughtful kind that looks at people in their orbits, proactively identifies needs, real or potential, and tries to match them up with resources to hand.

(insert gospel choir here)

Whether or not I personally knew or even liked the people who were recognized, I could point to many generous, kind or thoughtful things I knew each person had done, not as part of a checklist drawn up in expectation of an audit but rather a balance of mindful action and heartfelt impulse, again focussing on individual needs.

Oh hell, I had some better words this morning but this will have to do.

I really welcome comments on this one.
